abstractText: Given a graph G, a dominating set of G is a set S of vertices such that each vertex not in S has a neighbor in S. The domination number of G, denoted γ(G), is the minimum size of a dominating set of G. The independent domination number of G, denoted i(G), is the minimum size of a dominating set of G that is also independent. Recently, Abrishami and Henning proved that if G is a cubic graph with girth at least 6, then i(G) ≤ 4 11 |V (G)|. We show a result that not only improves upon the upper bound of the aforementioned result, but also applies to a larger class of graphs, and is also tight. Namely, we prove that if G is a cubic graph without 4-cycles, then i(G) ≤ 5 14 |V (G)|, which is tight. Our result also implies that every cubic graph G without 4-cycles satisfies i(G) γ(G) ≤ 54 , which partially answers a question by O and West in the affirmative.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction

All graphs in this paper are finite and simple. Given a graph G, let V (G) and E(G) denote the
vertex set and the edge set, respectively, of G. A dominating set of G is a subset S of V (G) such
that each vertex not in S has a neighbor in S. The domination number of G, denoted γ(G), is
the minimum size of a dominating set of G. Domination is an extensively studied classic topic in
graph theory, to the point that there are several books focused solely on domination, see [8–11].

A dominating set of a graph G that is also an independent set in G is an independent dom-
inating set of G. The independent domination number of G, denoted i(G), is the minimum size
of an independent dominating set of G. Note that every graph has an independent dominating
set, as a maximal independent set is equivalent to an independent dominating set. This concept
appeared in the literature as early as 1962 by Berge [2] and Ore [15]. For a survey regarding
independent domination, see [5].
For a connected k-regular graph G where k ≥ 1, Rosenfeld [16] showed that i(G) ≤ |V (G)| 2 , which is tight only for the balanced complete bipartite graph Kk,k. The next natural step is to try to improve the upper bound on the independent domination number when the balanced
complete bipartite graph is excluded. Extending a result by Lam, Shiu, and Sun [13], Cho, Choi,
and Park [3] recently proved the following result:
Theorem 1.1 ( [3]). For k ≥ 3, if G is a connected k-regular graph that is not Kk,k, then i(G) ≤ k−1
2k−1 |V (G)|.
Note that the bound in Theorem 1.1 is tight for k ∈ {3, 4} by C5 K2 and the 4-regular expansion of a 7-cycle, but the tightness of the bound is unknown for k ≥ 5. See the two left figures of Figure 1 for an illustration. To our knowledge, this is the best upper bound on the
independent domination number not only for cubic graphs, but also for regular graphs in general.
Another popular way to exclude the complete bipartite graph is to impose restrictions on cycle
lengths. Recall that the girth of a graph is the length of a smallest cycle in the graph. According
to [5], the following conjecture was made by Verstraëte:
Conjecture 1.2 (see [5]). If G is a cubic graph with girth at least 6, then i(G) ≤ |V (G)| 3 .
The girth condition in the conjecture cannot be reduced by the right graph of Figure 1,
as it has 14 vertices, girth 5, and independent domination number 5. Note that Duckworth
and Wormald [4] constructed an infinite family of connected cubic graphs with girth 5 whose independent domination number is exactly |V (G)| 3 . For other results regarding the independent domination number of cubic graphs with girth 5, see [7].
Graphs without odd cycles, namely bipartite graphs, is also an intensively researched class of
graphs. Goddard et al. [6] made the following conjecture regarding the independent domination
number of bipartite cubic graphs:
Conjecture 1.3 ( [6]). If G is a connected bipartite cubic graph that is not K3,3, then i(G) ≤ 4 11 |V (G)|.
If the above conjecture is true, then it is tight by a graph displayed in [6]. Henning, Löwenstein,
and Rautenbach [12] showed that Conjecture 1.3 is true if a 4-cycle is also forbidden, so the
conjecture is true for bipartite cubic graphs with girth at least 6. Recently, in 2018, Abrishami
and Henning [1] improved the aforementioned result by showing that the same conclusion holds
when the bipartite condition (but keeping the restriction on the girth) is removed. The following
is the result by Abrishami and Henning:
Theorem 1.4 ( [1]). If G is a cubic graph with girth at least 6, then i(G) ≤ 4 11 |V (G)|.
Our main result improves Theorem 1.4 in a strong sense. We not only improve the bound from 4 11 to 5 14 , but also enlarge the class of graphs the theorem applies to. Moreover, the new bound is also tight, by the right graph in Figure 1, which has 14 vertices and independent domination
number 5. We now explicitly state our main result:
Theorem 1.5. If G is a cubic graph without 4-cycles, then i(G) ≤ 5 14 |V (G)|.
Recall that both K3,3 and C5 K2 must be excluded, which is done by the restriction on the 4-cycle. Moreover, in [6], there are infinitely many connected cubic graphs G satisfying i(G) = 3 8 |V (G)|, which all have 4-cycles.
We actually prove a stronger statement, which applies to subcubic graphs. Note that Theo-
rem 1.5 is a direct consequence of the following theorem:
Theorem 1.6. If G is a subcubic graph without 4-cycles, then 14i(G) ≤ 14n0(G) + 9n1(G) + 6n2(G) + 5n3(G), where ni(G) denotes the number of vertices of degree i in G.
There are infinitely many connected graphs that are tight for the above result. Some simple
ones are the edgeless graph, the 7-cycle, and the right graph in Figure 1. We now construct an
infinite family of connected graphs that are tightness examples. For non-negative integers k and ` satisfying k+ ` ≥ 5, let Tk,` be the graph obtained from a (k+ 4`)-cycle x1 . . . xk+4`x1 by adding a pendent vertex to each of x1, . . . , xk, and adding a vertex joining xk+4i+1 and xk+4i+4 for each i ∈ {0, . . . , `− 1} (see Figure 2). Then n0(Tk,`) = 0, n1(Tk,`) = k, n2(Tk,`) = 3`, n3(Tk,`) = k+ 2`, and i(Tk,`) = k + 2`. Hence, equality in Theorem 1.6 holds.
Disproving a conjecture by Henning and Southey [17], O and West [14] constructed an infinite
family of 2-connected cubic graphs G satisfying i(G) γ(G) = 5 4 . They asked if this is best possible.
Question 1.7 ( [14]). Does i(G) γ(G) ≤ 5 4 hold for a connected cubic graph G on sufficiently many vertices?
We answer this question in the affirmative for cubic graphs without 4-cycles.
Theorem 1.8. If G is a cubic graph without 4-cycles, then i(G) γ(G) ≤ 5 4 .
As all 2-connected cubic graphs G satisfying i(G) γ(G) = 5 4 provided in [14] have a 4-cycle, we raise
the following question:
Question 1.9. Is there a cubic graph G without 4-cycles satisfying i(G) γ(G) = 5 4 ?
We prove Theorem 1.6 and Theorem 1.8 in Section 2 and Section 3, respectively. We end this
section with some definitions frequently used.
Given a graph G and X ⊆ V (G), let G[X] denote the subgraph of G induced by X, and let G−X denote the subgraph of G induced by V (G) \X. For X ⊆ V (G), let ∂G(X) be the set of edges whose one end is in X and the other end is in G − X. For a vertex v ∈ V (G), let dG(v) denote the degree of v in G. For a non-negative integer k, a vertex v is a k-vertex if dG(v) = k, and a k-neighbor of v is a neighbor of v that is also a k-vertex. A 2-step neighbor of v is a vertex
that can reach v by a path of length 2. A 2-step k-neighbor of v is a 2-step neighbor that is a
k-vertex. For a non-negative integer k, let nk(G) denote the number of k-vertices of G. For each vertex v ∈ V (G), let NG(v) denote the set of neighbors of v, and let NG[v] = NG(v) ∪ {v}. For X ⊆ V (G), let NG(X) = ⋃ v∈X NG(v) and NG[X] = NG(X) ∪X. For v ∈ V (G) and X ⊆ V (G), an X-vertex is a vertex in X, and an X-neighbor of v is a neighbor of v that is in X. Throughout
the paper, if it is clear which graph we are referring to, then we will simply use d(v), N(v),
N [v], N [X], and ∂(X), instead of dG(v), NG(v), NG[v], NG[X], and ∂G(X), respectively. For {v1, . . . , vk} ⊆ V (G), we simply write N [v1, . . . , vk] instead of N [{v1, . . . , vk}].

Given a vertex v of a subcubic graph G, its weight wG(v) is defined as follows:
wG(v) =  14 if d(v) = 0 9 if d(v) = 1 6 if d(v) = 2
5 if d(v) = 3
The weight of a non-empty set X ⊆ V (G), denoted wG(X), is defined by wG(X) = ∑ v∈X wG(v), and the weight of the entire graph G, denoted w(G), is the weight of V (G). That is,
w(G) = w(V (G)) = ∑
v∈V (G) wG(v) = 14n0(G) + 9n1(G) + 6n2(G) + 5n3(G).
For a non-empty subset X of V (G), we denote the sum of weight changes of the vertices in G−X by cG(X). That is,
cG(X) = ∑
v∈V (G−X) (wG−X(v)− wG(v)) = w(G−X)− (w(G)− wG(X)).
To show Theorem 1.6, suppose to the contrary that there exists a counterexample, and let G
be a counterexample with the minimum number of vertices and edges. This implies that G is a
subcubic graph without 4-cycles satisfying 14i(G) > w(G), and every proper subgraph H of G satisfies 14i(H) ≤ w(H). If G is the disjoint union of two graphs G1 and G2, then by the minimality of G,
14i(G) = 14i(G1) + 14i(G2) ≤ w(G1) + w(G2) = w(G),
which is a contradiction. Thus, G is connected. One can check that the theorem holds for all
graphs with at most four vertices, and all paths and cycles on at least five vertices. Thus, G is a
graph on at least five vertices and has a 3-vertex.
We will often use the following observation. For a vertex v, a vertex of G − N [v] cannot be adjacent to two vertices in N [v] since G has no 4-cycles. By the same reason, two vertices
cannot have two common neighbors. We now prove a key lemma that will be crucial in our future
arguments.
Key Lemma. If S is an independent set of G, then 14|S| > wG(N [S])− cG(N [S]).
Proof. Let U = N [S], and let S ′ be a minimum independent dominating set of G − U . By the minimality of G, we have w(G−U) ≥ 14i(G−U) = 14|S ′|. Since S is an independent dominating set of G[U ] and S ∪S ′ is an independent set, S ∪S ′ is an independent dominating set of G. Since
14|S|+ 14|S ′| ≥ 14i(G) > w(G) = w(G− U) + wG(U)− cG(U) ≥ 14|S ′|+ wG(U)− cG(U),
we obtain the desired conclusion.
Our first goal is to prove that G has no 1-vetices. We first lay out some structural observations.
Claim 2.1. The following do not appear in the graph G:
(i) A vertex with two 1-neighbors.
(ii) A vertex with only 2−-neighbors.
(iii) A 3-vertex with a 1-neighbor and a 2-neighbor.
(iv) A triangle vuwv such that v has a 1-neighbor.
(v) A triangle with a 2-vertex.
(vi) A path vuw such that v, u, w are 3-vertices, v has a 1-neighbor and u has no 1-neighbor.
Proof. In the following, let v be a vertex, and let ti be the number of i-neighbors of v, so t1 + t2 + t3 = d(v). Let U = N [v], so wG(U) = 9t1 + 6t2 + 5t3 + wG(v).
(i): Suppose to the contrary that t1 ≥ 2. Then wG(U) ≥ 9 · 2 + min{6, 5 + 5, 5 + 6} = 24 and |∂(U)| ≤ 2. If G−U has two isolated vertices, then G is a tree on 6 vertices, so 14i(G) = 14 · 3 = 42 ≤ 46 = 9 · 4 + 5 · 2 = w(G), which is a contradiction. Thus G − U has at most one isolated vertex, so cG(U) ≤ 5 + 3 = 8. By the Key Lemma, 14 > 24− 8, which is a contradiction. Hence (i) holds.
Actually, by the same logic, we know that cG(U) ≤ 5t2 + (5 + 3)t3 = 5t2 + 8t3. Note that every 3-neighbor of v has at most one 1-neighbor by (i). By the Key Lemma,
14 > 9t1 + 6t2 + 5t3 + wG(v)− (5t2 + 8t3) = 9t1 + t2 − 3t3 + wG(v).
(ii): Suppose to the contrary that t3 = 0, and assume v is such a vertex with minimum degree. If t1 ≥ 1, then by the Key Lemma, 14 > 9t1 + t2 + wG(v) ≥ 9 + 5, which is a contradiction, so t1 = 0. Therefore, all neighbors of v are 2-vertices.
Suppose that v is a 1-vertex, and let u be the neighbor of v. Since G is a graph on at least 5 vertices, the neighbor w of u that is not v must be a 2+-vertex. Since wG(U) = 9 + 6 = 15, and cG(U) ∈ {1, 3}, the Key Lemma implies cG(U) = 3, so w must be a 2-vertex. Now, we know
wG(N [u]) = 9 + 6 · 2 = 21 and cG(N [u]) ≤ 5. The Key Lemma implies 14 > 21 − 5, which is a contradiction. In particular, there is no 1-vertex with a 2−-neighbor.
Now suppose that d(v) ≥ 2. Since there is no 1-vertex with a 2−-neighbor, the 2-step neighbors of v are 2+-vertices.
If v is a 2-vertex, then wG(U) = 6 · 3 = 18. Since G is not a cycle, we can take v to be a vertex such that at least one 2-step neighbor of v is a 3-vertex. Since G has no 4-cycle, cG(U) ≤ 3 + 1 = 4, so the Key Lemma implies 14 > 18 − 4, which is a contradiction. If v is a 3-vertex, then wG(U) = 6 · 3 + 5 = 23 and cG(U) ≤ 3 · 3 = 9, so the Key Lemma implies 14 > 23− 9, which is a contradiction. Hence (ii) holds.
(iii): Suppose to the contrary that v is a 3-vertex, t1 ≥ 1, and t2 ≥ 1. Then t1 = t2 = t3 = 1 by (ii), and therefore wG(U) = 9 + 6 + 5 · 2 = 25. By (ii), the 2-neighbor of v has no 1-neighbor and by (i), the 3-neighbor of v has at most one 1-neighbor, so cG(U) ≤ 5 + 3 · 2 = 11. The Key Lemma implies 14 > 25− 11, which is a contradiction. Hence (iii) holds.
(iv): Suppose to the contrary that there is a triangle vuwv such that v has a 1-neighbor. Then wG(U) ≥ 9 + 5 · 3 = 24 and cG(U) ≤ 5 · 2 = 10. The Key Lemma implies 14 > 24− 10, which is a contradiction. Hence (iv) holds.
(v): Suppose to the contrary that there is a triangle vuwv such that v is a 2-vertex. If u is
a 2-vertex, then w must be a 3-vertex since G is a graph on at least 5 vertices. By (ii) and (iv), the neighbor of w not on vuwv must be a 3-vertex, so wG(U) ≥ 6 · 2 + 5 = 17 and cG(U) ≤ 1. The Key Lemma implies 14 > 17 − 1, which is a contradiction. Thus, u is a 3-vertex, and by symmetry, w is also a 3-vertex, so wG(U) = 6 + 5 · 2 = 16. Let u′, w′ be the neighbor of u,w, respectively, that is not on the triangle vuwv. Note that u′ 6= w′ since G has no 4-cycles. By (iv), both u′ and w′ are 2+-vertices. If u′, w′ are 3-vertices, then cG(U) ≤ 1 · 2 = 2, so the Key Lemma implies 14 > 16 − 2, which is a contradiction. Without loss of generality, let u′ be a 2-vertex. Note that u′ has no 1-neighbor by (ii). Now, wG(N [u]) ≥ 6 ·2+5 ·2 = 22 and cG(N [u]) ≤ 3 ·2 = 6. The Key Lemma implies 14 > 22− 6, which is a contradiction. Hence (v) holds.
(vi): Suppose to the contrary that there is a path vuw such that v, u, w are 3-vertices, v has
a 1-neighbor, and u has no 1-neighbor. By (i) and (iii), v has a 3-neighbor x other than u. Note that x 6= w by (iv). By (iii), cG(U) ≤ 1+3+max{5+1, 3+3} = 10. Since wG(U) ≥ 9+5 ·3 = 24, the Key Lemma implies 14 > 24− 10, which is a contradiction. Hence (vi) holds.
Claim 2.2. The graph G has no 1-vertex.
Proof. Suppose to the contrary that G has a 1-vertex. Let X be the set of 3-vertices with 1-
neighbors. Note that G[X] has maximum degree at most 2 and X is not empty since every
1-vertex is adjacent to a 3-vertex by Claim 2.1 (ii). Take a component P of G[X]. If P is a cycle, then G is isomorphic to Tk,0 for some k ≥ 3 (see Figure 2), which is a contradiction to our assumption that 14i(G) > w(G). Thus P is a path, and let u1 be an end vertex of P . Let
N(u1) = {v1, u2, x}, where v1 is the 1-neighbor of u1 and x 6∈ X. By Claim 2.1 (i), (iii), and (iv), x and u2 are 3-vertices and xu2 6∈ E(G). Let N(x) = {u1, x1, x2}. We know x1 and x2 are 2-vertices by Claim 2.1 (vi).
(Case 1) Suppose that u2 is on P . Let N(u2) = {v2, y, u1}, where v2 is the 1-neighbor of u2. By Claim 2.1 (i), (iii), and (iv), y is a 3-vertex distinct from x. Let N(y) = {u2, y1, y2}. Note that xy /∈ E(G) since G has no 4-cycles. See the first figure of Figure 3 for an illustration. Suppose that u1 is not on a 6-cycle. Consider G
′ = (G − {u1, u2, v1, v2}) + xy. Since G′ is a subcubic graph without 4-cycles, by the minimality of G, 14i(G′) ≤ w(G′). We can always add two vertices in {u1, u2, v1, v2} to a minimum independent dominating set of G′ to obtain an independent dominating set of G, so i(G) ≤ i(G′) + 2. Since w(G) = w(G′) + 28, we obtain 14i(G) ≤ 14i(G′) + 28 ≤ w(G′) + 28 = w(G), which is a contradiction. Thus u1 must be on a 6-cycle, say xu1u2yy1x1x.
Suppose y ∈ X, and assume y2 is a 1-neighbor of y. Then, y1 is a 3-vertex by Claim 2.1 (i) and (iii). Since x1 is a 2-neighbor of y1, Claim 2.1 (iii) implies y1 /∈ X. Now, wG(N [x, v1, v2, y]) = 9 · 3 + 6 · 2 + 5 · 5 = 64 and cG(N [x, v1, v2, y]) ≤ max{3 + 3, 8} = 8, so the Key Lemma implies 56 = 4·14 > 64−8 = 56, which is a contradiction. Thus y /∈ X. By Claim 2.1 (vi), y1 and y2 are 2- vertices. Now, wG(N [x1, v1, u2]) = 9·2+6·2+5·4 = 50 and cG(N [x1, v1, u2]) ≤ max{3+3, 8} = 8, so the Key Lemma implies 42 = 3 · 14 > 50− 8 = 42, which is a contradiction. (Case 2) Suppose that u2 is not on P . Let N(u2) = {u1, y1, y2}. By Claim 2.1 (vi), y1 and y2 are 2-vertices. For i ∈ {1, 2}, let x′i and y′i be the neighbor of xi and yi distinct from x and u2, respectively. See the second figure of Figure 3 for an illustration. Since G has no 4-cycles, x′1, x ′ 2, u2 are all distinct. If x ′ 1 and x ′ 2 are 3-vertices, then wG(N [x, v1]) = 9 + 6 · 2 + 5 · 2 = 31 and cG(N [x, v1]) ≤ 1 · 3 = 3, so the Key Lemma implies 28 = 2 · 14 > 31 − 3 = 28, which is a contradiction. Without loss of generality, we may assume x′1 is a 2-vertex. By symmetry, we may assume y′1 is a 2-vertex. (Case 2-1) Suppose that x′1x ′ 2 ∈ E(G) and y′1y′2 ∈ E(G). Note that x, u1, u2 cannot all be on
the same 5-cycle. Thus G′ = (G − {u1, v1}) + xu2 has no 4-cycles. By the minimality of G, 14i(G′) ≤ w(G′). Let S ′ be a minimum independent dominating set of G′. We will define an independent dominating set S of G of size |S ′| + 1. If S ′ does not contain a vertex in {x, u2}, then let S = S ′ ∪ {v1}. If x ∈ S ′, then exactly one of x′1, x′2 is in S ′, so when x′1 ∈ S ′ (resp. x′2 ∈ S ′), let S = (S ′ ∪ {x2, u1}) \ {x} (resp. S = (S ′ ∪ {x1, u1}) \ {x}). By symmetry, the case when u2 ∈ S is also resolved. In every case, i(G) ≤ i(G′) + 1. Since w(G) = w(G′) + 14, we have 14i(G) ≤ 14i(G′) + 14 ≤ w(G′) + 14 = w(G), which is a contradiction. (Case 2-2) Without loss of generality, suppose that x′1x ′ 2 6∈ E(G). Let x′′1 be the neighbor of x′1 distinct from x1. By Claim 2.1 (v), we know x ′′ 1 6= x. By Claim 2.1 (ii), x′′1 is a 3-vertex with a 3-neighbor. If x′′1 = u2, then wG(N [u1, x ′ 1]) = 9 + 6 · 2 + 5 · 3 = 36 and cG(N [u1, x′1]) ≤ 3 · 2 = 6, so the Key Lemma implies 28 = 2 · 14 > 36 − 6 = 30, which is a contradiction. Thus x′′1 6= u2, and wG(N [u1, x ′ 1]) = 9 + 6 · 2 + 5 · 4 = 41. If G − N [u1, x′1] has no isolated vertices, then cG(N [u1, x ′ 1]) ≤ 3 · 4 + 1 = 13, so the Key Lemma implies 28 = 2 · 14 > 41 − 13 = 28, which is a contradiction. Thus, G −N [u1, x′1] must have an isolated vertex. Since y′1 is a 2-vertex and x′1x
′ 2 6∈ E(G), we know x′′1y2 ∈ E(G). Let z be the neighbor of x′′1 distinct from x ′ 1 and y2, so z is a 3-vertex. Let y ′′ 1 be the neighbor of y′1 other than y1, so by Claim 2.1 (ii), y ′′ 1 is a 3-vertex. See the third figure of Figure 3 for an illustration. Since wG(N [x ′′ 1]) = 6 · 2 + 5 · 2 = 22, the Key Lemma implies cG(N [x′′1]) ≥ 9. Thus, together with Claim 2.1 (i) and (iii), we know that the neighbors of z other than x′′1 are either both 2-vertices or a 1-vertex and a 3-vertex. Since wG(N [x ′′ 1, y1]) = 6 · 4 + 5 · 3 = 39, by the Key Lemma, 28 = 2 · 14 > 39 − cG(N [x′′1, y1]), so cG(N [x′′1, y1]) ≥ 12. If z = y′′1 or zy′′1 6∈ E(G), then cG(N [x ′′ 1, y1]) ≤ 3+1 ·2+max{3+3, 1+5} = 11, which is a contradiction. Thus zy′′1 ∈ E(G), and moreover, z has a 1-neighbor. See the last figure of Figure 3 for an illustration.
Now wG(N [u1, x1, y2, y ′ 1, z]) = 9 · 2 + 6 · 5 + 5 · 6 = 78. Note that y′′1 has no 1-neighbor by Claim 2.1 (iii). So cG(N [u1, x1, y2, y ′ 1, z]) ≤ max{3 + 3, 8} = 8. By the Key Lemma, 70 = 5 · 14 > 78− 8, which is a contradiction.
We will now analyze the structure between 2-vertices and 3-vertices. In the following, let Ai be the set of 3-vertices with exactly i 2-neighbors, and let Bi be the set of 2-vertices with exactly i 2-neighbors. By Claim 2.1 (ii), A3 = B2 = ∅, so V (G) can be partitioned into A0, A1, A2, B0, and B1. Note that B0 is an independent set in G and G[B1] is the disjoint union of K2.
Claim 2.3. The following holds in the graph G:
(i) Each B1-vertex v has at least one 2-step 2-neighbor. In particular, v has a B1-neighbor and
an A2-neighbor.
(ii) Each Ai-vertex v has at least i+ 1 2-step 2-neighbors.
(ii)-1 If i = 2, then the three neighbors of v are in A2, B1, B1, or A1, B1, B1, or A2, B0, B1.
(ii)-2 If i = 0, then v has an A1-neighbor, which has an A2-neighbor.
Proof. (i): Let v ∈ B1, so v has a 2-neighbor v1 and a 3-neighbor v2. If v has no 2-step 2- neighbors, then wG(N [v]) = 6 · 2 + 5 = 17 and cG(N [v]) ≤ 1 · 3 = 3, so the Key Lemma implies 14 > 17 − 3, which is a contradiction. By Claim 2.1 (ii), v1 ∈ B1. Since v must have a 2-step 2-neighbor and v2 cannot have only 2-neighbors by Claim 2.1 (ii), we know v2 ∈ A2.
(ii): Suppose to the contrary that a vertex v ∈ Ai has at most i 2-step 2-neighbors. Then wG(N [v]) = 6 · i+ 5 · (4− i) = i+ 20 and cG(N [v]) ≤ 3 · i+ 1 · ((3− i) ·2) = i+ 6. The Key Lemma implies 14 > (i+ 20)− (i+ 6) = 14, which is a contradiction.
If i = 2, then the three neighbors of v are in A2, B1, B1, or A1, B1, B1, or A2, B0, B1. If i = 0, then v is an A0-vertex. Since an A2-vertex cannot have an A0-neighbor, v has no A2-neighbors. Since v must have a 2-step 2-neighbor w, the common neighbor u of w and v must be an A1-vertex. Since a B1-vertex cannot have an A1-neighbor by (i), w must be a B0-vertex. Since u must have two 2-step 2-neighbors, the 3-neighbor of u distinct from v is an A2-vertex.
Claim 2.4. The following holds in the graph G:
(i) The set A2 is not empty.
(ii) There is a cycle C : x1x2 . . . xkx1 in G[A2 ∪ B1] such that if xi, xi+1 ∈ A2, then xi has a B0-neighbor. In particular, each A2-vertex on C has at most one A2-neighbor on C and
each B1-vertex on C has exactly one B1-neighbor on C.
(iii) If two A2-vertices x, y have a common B0-neighbor v, then there is a 5-cycle vxx1y1yv such
that x1, y1 are B1-vertices.
Proof. (i): Suppose to the contrary that G has no A2-vertex. Claim 2.3 implies that there are neither B1-vertices nor A0-vertices. Thus, every 3-vertex has a 2-neighbor, so the set of 2-vertices is a dominating set. Since every 2-vertex is a B0-vertex, B0 dominates G. Moreover, B0 is an independent dominating set in G by definition, so i(G) ≤ n2(G). Also, n3(G) = 2n2(G) since there are no A2-vertices. Thus, w(G) = 6n2(G) + 5n3(G) = 16n2(G) ≥ 16i(G) > 14i(G), which is a contradiction. Hence, G must have some A2-vertices.
(ii): Note that there exists an A2-vertex v1 by (i). We find a cycle C : x1x2 . . . x1 of G[A2∪B1] containing v1 by the following algorithm: Let x1 = v1. Consider an A2-vertex xi on C. (The indices of the vertices on C are considered modulo k.) If xi has an B1-neighbor u1 that is not xi−1, then there is a path u1u2u3 where u1, u2 are B1-vertices and u3 is an A2-vertex by Claim 2.3 (i) and (ii). Let xi+1 = u1, xi+2 = u2, and xi+3 = u3. (Note that xixi+1xi+2xi+3 is indeed a path since xi 6= xi+3 by Claim 2.1 (v).) If the only B1-neighbor of xi is xi−1, then let xi+1 be the A2-neighbor of xi, which exists by Claim 2.3 (ii).
Since G is a finite graph, this algorithm must terminate. Note that each A2-vertex xi with xi+1 ∈ A2 must have an B0-neighbor by Claim 2.3 (ii). In particular, by the algorithm, each A2-vertex on C has at most one A2-neighbor on C and each B1-vertex on C has exactly one B1-neighbor on C.
(iii): By Claim 2.3 (ii), x and y have a B1-neighbor x1 and y1, respectively. Suppose to the contrary that x1y1 is not an edge. By Claim 2.3 (i), x1 has a 2-neighbor, so wG(N [x1, y]) = 6 · 4 + 5 · 3 = 39. By Claim 2.1 (ii), every 2-step neighbor of x1 not in N [x1, y] is a 3-vertex. By Claim 2.3 (ii), every 2-step neighbor of y not in N [x1, y] is a 2-vertex. Thus, cG(N [x1, y]) ≤ 3 · 3 + 1 · 2 = 11, so the Key Lemma implies 28 = 14 · 2 > 39− 11 = 28, which is a contradiction. Hence, x1y1 ∈ E(G), so vxx1y1yv is a 5-cycle.
By Claim 2.4 (ii), there is a cycle C : x1x2 . . . xkx1 in G[A2 ∪ B1] such that if xi, xi+1 ∈ A2, then xi has a B0-neighbor. (The indices of the vertices on C will always be considered modulo k.) Define the following subset of V (C):
X = {xi ∈ B1 | xi−1 ∈ A2, xi+1 ∈ B1}.
Let yi be the B0-neighbor of xi when xi, xi+1 ∈ A2, and let Y be the set of all yi’s. Note that X ∪ Y consists of 2-vertices, and X ∪ Y is an independent set in G by definition. Let Yj be the set of Y -vertices with exactly j A2-neighbors. If yi is a Y2-vertex, then yixixi−1xi−2xi−3yi is a 5-cycle by Claim 2.4 (iii). Thus, both neighbors of a Y2-vertex are (A2 ∩ V (C))-vertices, and one of them has an X-neighbor. See Figure 4 for an illustration.
Define the following two sets:
X∗ = {xi−1 | xi ∈ X} \N(Y ), Y ∗ = {zi | zi is the A1-neighbor of yi distinct from xi}.
Note that zi is an A1-vertex and is not on C, and |X∗| = |X| − |Y2| and |Y ∗| = |Y1|,
Claim 2.5. If X∗-vertices xi, xj have a common neighbor v 6∈ V (C), then v is a 3-vertex.
Proof. Suppose to the contrary that v is a 2-vertex. Since xi, xj are A2-vertices, we know v ∈ B0. By Claim 2.4 (iii), there is a 5-cycle xixi+1xi+2xjvxi, where xi+1, xi+2 are B1-vertices, so j = i+3. Since xi+3 is an X ∗-vertex, we obtain that xi+4 is a B1-vertex, which is a contradiction since now xi+3 has three 2-neighbors xi+2, xi+4, and v.
Claim 2.6. Two Y ∗-vertices do not have a common neighbor.
Proof. Suppose to the contrary that two distinct Y ∗-vertices zi and zj have a common neighbor v. Since each Y ∗-vertex is an A1-vertex, v must be a 3-vertex. Note that xi−1, xi−2 ∈ B1 and xi+1 ∈ A2, which further implies xi+1 is a 2-vertex in G−N [xi−1, zi].
Suppose v ∈ A0. Then wG(N [xi−1, zi]) = 6 · 3 + 5 · 4 = 38, and the neighbor of zi distinct from v and yi is an A2-vertex by Claim 2.3 (ii)-2. Thus if there is a common 2-step neighbor of xi−1 and zi, then v is adjacent to either xi−3 or xi+1, which is impossible since v ∈ A0 and xi−3, xi+1 ∈ A2. Thus cG(N [xi−1, zi]) ≤ 3 · 2 + 1 · 4 = 10, so the Key Lemma implies 28 > 38− 10, which is a contradiction. Thus v ∈ A1, so v has a B0-neighbor by Claim 2.3 (i).
Let U1 = N [v, xi, xj], so wG(U1) = 6 · 5 + 5 · 7 = 65. Note that every 2-step neighbor of v not in U1 is a 3-vertex, and every 2-step neighbor of xi or xj not in U1 is a 2-vertex. By Claim 2.5, if xi+1, xj+1 ∈ X∗ have a common neighbor u 6∈ V (C), then u is a 3-vertex, which is impossible since xi and xj are the 3-neighbors of xi+1 and xj+1, respectively. Thus, there are at most two vertices in G − U1 that are incident with two edges of ∂(U1), namely, xi−2 and xj−2. If there is at most one vertex in G−U1 that is incident with two edges of ∂(U1), then cG(U1) ≤ 8 + 3 · 4 + 1 · 3 = 23, so the Key Lemma implies 42 > 65 − 23 = 42, which is a contradiction. Thus, it must be that xi−2 = xj+2 and xj−2 = xi+2, so k = 8.
Without loss of generality, let i = 0 and j = 4. In this case, wG(N [x0, x3]) = 6 · 4 + 5 · 3 = 39 and cG(N [x0, x3]) ≤ 3 · 3 + 1 · 2 = 11, so the Key Lemma implies 28 > 39 − 11, which is a contradiction.
Let U = N [X ∪ Y ], so |U | = 3|X|+ 3|Y1|+ 2|Y2| and wG(U) = 17|X|+ 16|Y1|+ 11|Y2|. Note that G[U ] contains C as a subgraph and every edge in ∂(U) is incident with a vertex in X∗ ∪ Y ∗. By the Key Lemma, 14|X|+ 14|Y1|+ 14|Y2| = 14|X ∪ Y | > (17|X|+ 16|Y1|+ 11|Y2|)− cG(U), so
cG(U) > 3|X|+ 2|Y1| − 3|Y2|. (2.1)
Define the initial charge µ(u) for every vertex u ∈ X∗ ∪ Y ∗ ∪ (V (G) \ U) as below:
µ(u) =  −3 if u ∈ X∗, −2 if u ∈ Y ∗, wG−U(u)− wG(u) if u ∈ V (G) \ U.
Note that the sum of the initial charge is cG(U)− 3|X∗| − 2|Y ∗| = cG(U)− 3(|X| − |Y2|)− 2|Y1|, which is positive by (2.1). We distribute the charge by the following rule, so the sum of the total charge is preserved. Recall that every edge in ∂(U) is incident with a vertex in X∗ ∪ Y ∗. [Rule] Let uv ∈ ∂(U) where u ∈ U . If u ∈ X∗, then u sends −3 to v. If u ∈ Y ∗, then u sends −1 to v.
Let µ∗(u) be the final charge of each vertex u after applying the above rule. We will obtain a contradiction by proving that the final charge of each vertex in X∗∪Y ∗∪(V (G)\U) is non-positive.
Claim 2.7. µ∗(v) ≤ 0 for a vertex v ∈ X∗ ∪ Y ∗ ∪ (V (G) \ U).
Proof. Since an X∗-vertex is incident with at most one edge of ∂(U) and a Y ∗-vertex is incident with at most two edges of ∂(U), it is clear from the definitions that µ∗(v) ≤ 0 for a vertex v ∈ X∗ ∪ Y ∗. Suppose to the contrary that there is a vertex v ∈ V (G) \ U such that µ∗(v) > 0. Clearly, v is incident with a vertex in X∗ ∪ Y ∗. By [Rule], we have
wG−U(v)− wG(v) > 3|X∗ ∩N(v)|+ |Y ∗ ∩N(v)|. (2.2)
We divide the proof into two cases. (Case 1) Suppose that v has no Y ∗-neighbor, so v must have an X∗-neighbor. If |X∗∩N(v)| = 1, then wG−U(v)−wG(v) ≤ 3 = 3|X∗ ∩N(v)|, which is a contradiction to (2.2). If |X∗ ∩N(v)| = 3, then v is a 3-vertex in G, and wG−U(v)− wG(v) = 9 = 3|X∗ ∩N(v)|, which is a contradiction to (2.2). Thus |X∗ ∩N(v)| = 2. If v is a 3-vertex, then wG−U(v)− wG(v) = 4 < 6 = 3|X∗ ∩N(v)|, which is a contradiction to (2.2). Thus, v is a 2-vertex with only X∗-neighbors, which is a
contradiction to Claim 2.5. (Case 2) Suppose that v has a Y ∗-neighbor. By the definition of Y ∗, we see that v is a 3-vertex. By Claim 2.6, v has exactly one Y ∗-neighbor. If |X∗ ∩ N(v)| = 0, then wG−U(v) − wG(v) = 1 = 3|X∗ ∩ N(v)| + |Y ∗ ∩ N(v)|, which is a contradiction to (2.2). If |X∗ ∩ N(v)| = 1, then wG−U(v) − wG(v) = 4 = 3|X∗ ∩ N(v)| + |Y ∗ ∩ N(v)|, which is a contradiction to (2.2). Thus |X∗ ∩ N(v)| = 2, which implies that v is an A0-vertex, since X∗ ⊆ A2 and Y ∗ ⊆ A1. This is a contradiction since an A0-vertex is not adjacent to an A2-vertex.
By Claim 2.7, the final charge of each vertex is non-positive, and we reach a contradiction to
(2.1). Hence, the counterexample G cannot exist.

sections.heading: 3 Ratio of independent domination and domination
sections.text:
In this section, we prove Theorem 1.8. Given a graph G and v ∈ X ⊆ V (G), the X-external private neighborhood of a vertex v is defined by epn(v,X) = {u ∈ V (G) \X | NG[u] ∩X = {v}}.
A dominating set X of G inducing a graph with maximum degree at most 1 is a near independent
dominating set.
Lemma 3.1. For a near independent dominating set X of a cubic graph G, i(G) ≤ |X| + 1 2 n1(G[X]).
Proof. We use induction on n1(G[X]). If n1(G[X]) = 0, then X is an independent dominating set of G, so the statement holds since i(G) ≤ |X|. Now, assume n1(G[X]) > 0. Take a vertex v ∈ X with a neighbor in X. Since G is cubic, | epn(v,X)| ≤ 2. Take a maximal independent set I of G such that I ⊆ epn(v,X), and let X ′ = (X ∪ I) \ {v}. (Note that I = ∅ when epn(v,X) = ∅.) Then X ′ is a near independent dominating set of G such that |X ′| ≤ |X|+ 1 and n1(G[X ′]) ≤ n1(G[X])− 2, so by the inductive hypothesis, we have i(G) ≤ |X ′|+ 1
2 n1(G[X ′]) ≤ (|X|+1)+ 1 2 (n1(G[X])−2) = |X|+ 12n1(G[X]).
Proof of Theorem 1.8. Let G be a cubic graph without 4-cycles, and let D be a minimum dominating set of G with the minimum number of edges in G[D]. Suppose that a vertex v ∈ D has two neighbors in D. By the minimality of |D|, we have | epn(v,D)| = 1. Then D′ = (D∪ epn(v,D))\{v} is a dominating set of G. Note that |D′| = |D| and |E(G[D′])| < |E(G[D])|, which is a contradiction to the choice of D. Thus, every vertex in D has at most one neighbor in
D, so D is a near independent dominating set of G.
Let mi = ni(G[D]). Then
γ(G) = |D| = m0 +m1. (3.1)
If m0 ≥ m1, then (3.1) implies γ(G) ≥ 2m1, so together with Lemma 3.1, we have the desired inequality since
i(G) ≤ |D|+ 1 2 m1 ≤ γ(G) + 1 4 γ(G) = 5 4 γ(G).
If m0 ≤ m1, then (3.1) implies γ(G) ≥ 2m0, so by Theorem 1.5, it holds that
i(G) ≤ 5 14 |V (G)| ≤ 5 14 (4m0 + 3m1) = 5 14 (3γ(G) +m0) ≤ 5 14
( 3γ(G) + 1
2 γ(G)
) = 5
4 γ(G),
where the second inequality is from the fact that D is a dominating set of a cubic graph, and the
third equality is from (3.1).
